enrich_metadata.label: Oakland, California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Oakland, Alameda County, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco. Oakland's territory covers what was once a mosaic of coastal terrace prairie, oak woodland, and north coastal scrub. Its land served as a rich resource when its hillside oak and redwood timber were logged to build San Francisco, and Oakland's fertile flatland soils helped it become a prolific agricultural region. In the late 1860s, Oakland was selected as the western terminal of the Transcontinental Railroad. Following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, many San Franciscans relocated to Oakland, enlarging the city's population, increasing its housing stock and improving its infrastructure. It continued to grow in the 20th century with its busy port, shipyards, and a thriving automobile manufacturing industry. Oakland is known for its sustainability practices, including a top ranking for usage of electricity from renewable resources. Oakland is also known for its history of political activism, as well as its professional sports franchises and major corporations, which include health care, dot-com companies and manufacturers of household products. In addition, thanks to a steady influx of immigrants during the 20th century, along with thousands of African-American war-industry workers who relocated from the Deep South during the 1940s, Oakland is one of the most ethnically diverse major cities in the country.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Oakland,_California
enrich_metadata.comment: Oakland /ˈoʊklənd/ is a major West Coast port city in the U.S. state of California. Oakland is the third largest city in the San Francisco Bay Area, the eighth-largest city in California, and the 45th-largest city in the U.S. with a population of 413,775 as of 2014. It serves as a trade center for the San Francisco Bay Area; its Port of Oakland is the busiest port for San Francisco Bay, all of Northern California, and fifth busiest in the United States. Incorporated in 1852, Oakland is the county seat of Alameda County. It is also the principal city of the Bay Area Region known as the East Bay. The city is situated directly across the bay, six miles (9.7 km) east of San Francisco.

enrich_metadata.label: Merced, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Merced /mərˈsɛd/ (Spanish for "Mercy") is a city in, and the county seat of, Merced County in the San Joaquin Valley of Northern California. As of 2014, the city had a population of 81,743. Incorporated on April 1, 1889, Merced is a charter city that operates under a council-manager government. It is named after the Merced River, which flows nearby. Merced, known as the "Gateway to Yosemite," is less than two hours by automobile from Yosemite National Park to the east and Monterey Bay, the Pacific Ocean, and several beaches to the west. The community is served by the rail passenger service Amtrak, a major airline through Merced Regional Airport, and three bus lines. It is approximately 110 miles (180 km) from Sacramento, 130 miles (210 km) from San Francisco, 45 miles (72 km) from Fresno, and 270 miles (430 km) from Los Angeles. In 2005, the city became home to the tenth University of California campus, University of California, Merced (UC Merced), the first research university built in the U.S. in the 21st century.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Merced,_California

enrich_metadata.label: San Francisco
enrich_metadata.mention_address: SF, California, United States of America
enrich_metadata.abstract: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city in the United States—with a Census-estimated 2014 population of 852,469. The city and its surrounding areas are known as the San Francisco Bay Area, and are a part of the larger OMB designated San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland combined statistical area, the fifth most populous in the nation with an estimated population of 8.6 million. San Francisco (Spanish for Saint Francis) was founded on June 29, 1776, when colonists from Spain established Presidio of San Francisco at the Golden Gate and Mission San Francisco de Asís named for St. Francis of Assisi a few miles away. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought rapid growth, making it the largest city on the West Coast at the time. San Francisco became a consolidated city-county in 1856.After three-quarters of the city was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake and fire, San Francisco was quickly rebuilt, hosting the Panama-Pacific International Exposition nine years later. In World War II, San Francisco was the port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the Pacific Theater. After the war, the confluence of returning servicemen, massive immigration, liberalizing attitudes, along with the rise of the "hippie" counterculture, the Sexual Revolution, the Peace Movement growing from opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War, and other factors led to the Summer of Love and the gay rights movement, cementing San Francisco as a center of liberal activism in the United States. Politically, the city votes strongly along liberal Democratic Party lines. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination, known for its cool summers, fog, steep rolling hills, eclectic mix of architecture, and landmarks including the Golden Gate Bridge, cable cars, the former Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, Fisherman's Wharf, and its Chinatown district. San Francisco is also the headquarters of five major banking institutions and various other companies such as Levi Strauss & Co., Gap Inc., Salesforce.com, Dropbox, Reddit, Square, Inc., Dolby, Airbnb, Weebly, Pacific Gas and Electric Company, Yelp, Pinterest, Twitter, Uber, Mozilla, Wikimedia Foundation, and Craigslist. It has several nicknames, including "The City by the Bay", "Fog City", "San Fran", and "Frisco", as well as older ones like "The City that Knows How", "Baghdad by the Bay", and "The Paris of the West". As of 2015, San Francisco was ranked high on world livability rankings.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/San_Francisco
enrich_metadata.comment: San Francisco (/sæn frənˈsɪskoʊ/), officially the City and County of San Francisco, is the cultural, commercial, and financial center of Northern California and the only consolidated city-county in California. San Francisco encompasses a land area of about 46.9 square miles (121 km2) on the northern end of the San Francisco Peninsula, which makes it the smallest county in the state. It has a density of about 18,187 people per square mile (7,022 people per km2), making it the most densely settled large city (population greater than 200,000) in the state of California and the second-most densely populated major city in the United States after New York City. San Francisco is the fourth-most populous city in California, after Los Angeles, San Diego and San Jose, and the 13th-most populous city

enrich_metadata.label: Sonora, California
enrich_metadata.abstract: Not to be confused with Sonoma, California. Sonora is the county seat of Tuolumne County, California. The city population was 4,903 during the 2010 Census, up from 4,423 during the 2000 Census. Sonora is the only incorporated community in Tuolumne County.
enrich_metadata.subject: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sonora,_California
enrich_metadata.mention_address: Sonora, Tuolumne County, California, United States of America

attraction_reviewComments: What incredible landscapes. We kept thinking we were not seeing what we were seeing. So much natural beauty. The sunrise was spectacular and well worth getting up early for.
I love it here, the landscape is amazing, crazy rocks all over the place. Many famous movies had scenes recorded here, as star wars, iron man...very close to Lone Pine and Death... read more
We took an unplanned detour to the Alabama Hills due to having extra time and we are really glad we did! This place is amazing. We got there around sunset and probably saw it in... read more
I have been all over the US and this has definitely been one of my favorite places I've ever seen. Such a unique and stunning place. Beautiful slate-grey mountains with brown... read more
This is a fantastic place to explore. The rock formations are like none I’ve ever seen anywhere! You will see so many cool natural arches, balanced rocks, and unusual rock... read more
Whoever expected the Alabama Hills to be in the Sierra Nevada Mountains in Lone Pine, California?!? Seriously, there is such a place that was used for the backgrounds to film a... read more
While the area is sought out by movie buffs, the topography of this area lends itself to a fantastic day of walking amongst the unique terrain. Sure the movie history is... read more
This was named for the CSS Alabama, a magnificent ship given to us by the British Government. Raphael Semmes was her captain. He was from Charles County, Maryland. The hills... read more
On the outskirts of Lone Tree, CA, between the town and Mt. Whitney, there is a semi-desert badlands filledwith trails, eroded rock formations and memories of classic movies shoot... read more
Hundreds of westerns and many Sci-fi classics (including scenes from Star Wars) have been shot in this iconic location. With a few simple tips, you can bring back some tremendous... read more
These hills, located a little west of Lone Pine are an amazing jumble of rocks. You can drive or hike around in them. If you have a good imagination, you can find different... read more
We stayed in Lone Pine after traveling through Death Valley NP and fell in love with this town (Actually on Lone Pine/Paiute-Shoshone Reservation). Alabama Hills were one of those... read more
I love this area and you can find some places off the tourist trail where it's just you and the elements. Mt Whitney range is just 5 minutes from Lone Pine town. You will find... read more
Loved the peaceful location, the history, the fresh air, and the awesome geology of Alabama Hills. Great place to hike, draw or paint landscapes en plein air.
Stopped in here on way to Death Valley after late spring skiing in Mammoth to see Mobius Arch. Really cool, unusual geography that you don't suspect is out there from the views... read more
On a clear day, this is a wonderful place to hike and enjoy a plethora of wind-carved conglomerate rock formations, natural arches, year-round mountain-fed streams. Camping is... read more
You do need to pay attention for snakes, etc. but the terrain is really unusual and fun to engage. Apparently lots of movies have been made up in this area.
Driving through the fantastic rock formations is exciting enough and could easily take a day or more to explore. Add the film history and hunting for particular rocks featured in... read more
This is a self-guided tour of famous movie sites, mostly old westerns but also a few others. We enjoyed every minute though the road is pretty rough and bumpy. There are hiking... read more
We especially liked the hike to the Arch that frames Mt. Whitney. We had a blast driving around looking for the different Movie Scenes and the the over 400 hundred climbing... read more
Was here to climb, didn't do the movie tour thing, but would be interesting with a family group. Lots of great moderate climbing, almost the same rock as Joshua Tree, but with... read more
Spent an afternoon here and want to go back when I have more time. So many unusual rocks to explore. Lots of hiking trails. Went to film museum first, so I could visualize where... read more
Don't be fooled by the hills you see as you enter Lone Pine on 395 from the south. They are not the Alabama Hills. Drive back Whitney Portal road and experience another world... read more
The tourist info sent us to view the hills, a beautiful spot with snow capped mountains all around. We just did a short trail through the boulder which you could walk through... read more
We passed on breakfast in our dingy motel and came here instead - great choice! Had a lovely breakfast - fast and delicious!
I always take a little time to visit the hills as I pass through Lone Pine. Old timers and some youth will remember seeing these hills in the old Saturday matinee movies. I like... read more
A quick drive out of Lone Pine brings you to Movie Flat Road. Lots of interesting rocks that make for great pictures of the Sierra Crest.
Unique geographic area. Fun camping, just watch for rattlesnakes! Good off roading and views. Nice hikes including views of Mt Whitney. A wonderful place to do photography.
We needed more time! We spent a few hours and saw many of the 'notable' formations, but could have spent a few more hours. Wish we'd have planned another night in Lone Pine, a... read more
Went during the film festival in October and had a great time. This is where a bunch of the old westerns where filmed and they put photo stills near the rocks so you can see what... read more
Full of nostalgic Movie history, as are all the local restaurants & hotels/motels. You could loose yourself 'quite literally' for days in these hills. Stunningly beautiful hikes... read more
Wander through the old cowboy movie locations and see bunchs of rock formations that you will recognize from old movies. Truly cool for the older folks (like me)
what a great place to visit. Can drive around for hours round the hills great fun. And the view of the mountains are beautiful. Been here many times and always enjoy t.
If you are in Lone Pine do not miss this place. One of the Earth’s oldest geological formations. They are a part of the Sierra Nevada mountains.
We only had a short time to drive through the hills where so many of the classic old westerns were filmed. Next time I would be sure to get info on hiking trails and would spend... read more
Easy to follow signs and take your camera. You will want some photos. Take a jacket as it could get chilly.
The variety of stone formations made hiking around just the best! We were climbing rocks and taking tons of pictures. Beautiful. I hadn't seen the movies shot in the different... read more
It such a pretty place. I do really recognize so much of it from films. It also has me wanting to see more filmed in the area.
The desert terrain and red rocks with the Sierra Nevada in the background is a wonderful sight !! We camped there in an RV and the night sky was unbelievable with no light... read more
Driving through the Alabama Hills outside of Lone Pine is like going back to those Saturday afternoon matinee movies when you were a kid. And besides that, the view of the east... read more
